BG425 |- |} In the 2003 version, the codes were as follows: : BG1 North Bulgaria :: BG11 North West ::: BG111 [[Vidin Province|Vidin]] ::: BG112 [[Montana Province|Montana]] ::: BG113 [[Vratsa Province|Vratsa]] :: BG12 North Central ::: BG121 [[Pleven Province|Pleven]] ::: BG122 [[Lovech Province|Lovech]] ::: BG123 [[Veliko Tarnovo Province|Veliko Tarnovo]] ::: BG124 [[Gabrovo Province|Gabrovo]] ::: BG125 [[Ruse Province|Ruse]] :: BG13 North East ::: BG131 [[Varna Province|Varna]] ::: BG132 [[Dobrich Province|Dobrich]] ::: BG133 [[Shumen Province|Shumen]] ::: BG134 [[Targovishte Province|Targovishte]] ::: BG135 [[Razgrad Province|Razgrad]] ::: BG136 [[Silistra Province|Silistra]] : BG2 South Bulgaria :: BG21 South West ::: BG211 [[Grad Sofiya]] ::: BG212 [[Sofiya Province|Sofiya]] ::: BG213 [[Blagoevgrad Province|Blagoevgrad]] ::: BG214 [[Pernik Province|Pernik]] ::: BG215 [[Kyustendil Province|Kyustendil]] :: BG22 South Central ::: BG221 [[Plovdiv Province|Plovdiv]] ::: BG222 [[Stara Zagora Province|Stara Zagora]] ::: BG223 [[Haskovo Province|Haskovo]] ::: BG224 [[Pazardzhik Province|Pazardzhik]] ::: BG225 [[Smolyan Province|Smolyan]] ::: BG226 [[Kardzhali Province|Kardzhali]] :: BG23 South East ::: BG231 [[Burgas Province|Burgas]] ::: BG232 [[Sliven Province|Sliven]] ::: BG233 [[Yambol Province|Yambol]] ==Local administrative units== {{main|Local administrative unit}} Below the NUTS levels, the two LAU (Local Administrative Units) levels are: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Level ! Subdivisions ! # |- ! LAU 1 | [[Municipalities of Bulgaria|Municipalities]] (''Obshtini'') | align="right" | 264 |- ! LAU 2 | Settlements (''Naseleni mesta'') | align="right" | 5302 |} ''The LAU codes of Bulgaria can be downloaded here:'' {{XLSlink|[http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/excel_files/BG_LAU_2007.xls]}}'' ==NUTS 2 regions redrawing== Some of the present NUTS II regions of Bulgaria no longer meet the relevant technical requirements, mostly due to general population decline and increasing regional disproportion. A 2013 study by FLGR Consult commissioned by the Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works analyzed the state and trends of change in the characteristics of these regions to identify several options for the pending redrawing of the NUTS II map of the country. The process was restarted in 2017 with certain modified versions considered, and final decision due by the end of 2018.S. Okov. [https://web.archive.org/web/20180228190530/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-26/bulgaria-may-redraw-regional-borders-to-maintain-flow-of-eu-cash Bulgaria May Redraw Regional Borders to Maintain Flow of EU Cash.] Bloomberg, 26 February 2018L. Ivanov. [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/321162634_NUTS_II_Regions_of_Bulgaria NUTS II Regions of Bulgaria:] Proposal submitted to the inter-ministerial working group on the development of options for the redrawing of Bulgarian NUTS Level 2 Boundaries. Sofia, November 2017 (in Bulgarian and English) The relevant Regional Development (Amendment) Bill, released for public consultation by the Council of Ministers in October 2018, is based on a four-regions version chosen from the shortlist of three options developed by an inter-ministerial working group lead by the Ministry of Regional Development and Public Works.[http://www.strategy.bg/PublicConsultations/View.aspx?lang=bg-BG&Id=3793 Regional Development (Amendment) Bill.] Council of Ministers: Portal for Public Consultation, 4 October – 6 November 2018 (in Bulgarian) File: Bulgaria_NUTS-2_Proposal_2018_variant_1.svg| Proposal option 1 File: Bulgaria_NUTS-2_Proposal_2018_variant_2.svg| Proposal option 2 underlying the Regional Development (Amendment) Bill of October 2018 File: Bulgaria_NUTS-2_Proposal_2018_variant_3.svg| Proposal option 3 File: Bulgaria_NUTS-2_Proposal_2018_variant_4.svg| Proposal option 4 File: Bulgaria_NUTS-2_Proposal_2018_variant_5.svg| Proposal option 5 ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Bulgaria]] * [[ISO 3166-2:BG|ISO 3166-2 codes of Bulgaria]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (A-C)#BU: Bulgaria|FIPS region codes of Bulgaria]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/codelist_en.cfm?list=nuts Hierarchical list of the Nomenclature of territorial units for statistics - NUTS and the Statistical regions of Europe] * [https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/345175/7451602/NUTS1-2013-EN.pdf Overview map of EU Countries - NUTS level 1] ** [https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/345175/7451602/2016-NUTS-2-map-BG.pdf BULGARIA - NUTS level 2] ** [https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/345175/7451602/2016-NUTS-3-map-BG.pdf BULGARIA - NUTS level 3] * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/ramon/nuts/introannex_regions_en.html Correspondence between the NUTS levels and the national administrative units] * [http://simap.europa.eu/codes-and-nomenclatures/codes-nuts/codes-nuts-table_en.htm List of current NUTS codes] ** [http://simap.europa.eu/codes-and-nomenclatures/codes-nuts/nuts_2008.ods Download current NUTS codes (ODS format)] * [http://www.statoids.com/ubg.html Regions of Bulgaria], Statoids.com {{NUTS}} [[Category:Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics|Bulgaria]] [[Category:Subdivisions of Bulgaria|Nuts]]

{{other uses|Mamre (disambiguation)}} {{about|the Russian Orthodox monastery and ancient tree at Hebron|the ancient site and oak/terebinth outside historical Hebron|Mamre}} [[File:Monastery in Hebron.jpg|thumb|210px|upright|In the monastery of the [[Holy Trinity]].]]
The '''Oak of Mamre''' (also called the '''Oak of Sibta'''), at Khirbet es-Sibte (also as Ain Sibta), is a site venerated by some as the "'''Oak of Abraham'''", and distinct from the more ancient site of [[Mamre]]. It owes its name to an ancient tree, which seems to be dead but has a young sprig growing next to it, and stands on the grounds of the modern [[Russian Orthodox]] [[Abraham's Oak Holy Trinity Monastery|Monastery of the Holy Trinity]].
The site is located {{convert|2|km|spell=in|abbr=off}} southwest of Mamre, historically near [[Hebron]]<ref>'''Genesis 13:18''' ''Then Abram removed his tent, and came and dwelt in the plain of Mamre, which is in Hebron, and built there an altar unto the LORD''(KJV)</ref> and now inside the city. Also called ''The Oak of Abraham'',<ref>The Hebrew term ''Eloney Mamreh'' of Genesis 13:18 is considered by some translators to be a name of a region in Canaan. Other scholars dispute this and suggest that it is the reference to the terebinth trees of Mamre; or to the ''Oak of Mamre'', which is now known as ''Abraham's Oak''</ref> it is an ancient tree which, in one tradition, is said to mark the place where [[Abraham]] entertained the three angels<ref>[http://www.stetson.edu/~psteeves/relnews/hebron.html ''New Challenge for Arafat: A Russian Church''] by Serge Schmemann for the New York Times, July 11, 1997.</ref> or where Abraham pitched his tent.
This site is distinct and at a different location from the site considered as Mamre by [[Herod the Great]], [[Josephus]], [[Constantine the Great]], early Church historians and Christian pilgrims all until the mid-12th century, such as [[Arculf]] and [[Abbot Daniel]]. That site is at a location called in Arabic Ramat al-Khalil (the older name used by archaeologists) and currently Bir al-Haram ar-Rameh, which is a few kilometres north of the site described in this article. After the mid-12th century, the tradition of the "Oak of Mamre" has migrated to one or several places along the road from Mamre to Hebron, such as the site from this article.
==History== [[File:Avraham oak 1912.jpg|thumb|Abraham's Oak in 1912.]] [[File:Hebron Yeshiva students, c. 1920s.png|thumb|Students of the [[Hebron Yeshiva|Slabodka Yeshiva]] at the Oak of Mamre c. 1927.]] [[File:Oak of Mamre 1.jpg|thumb|The Oak of Mamre in 2008.]]
As written in a footnote from an 1895 publication of Arculf's pilgrimage report, "[t]he Oak or Terebinth of Abraham has been shown in two different sites. Arculf and many others ([[Jerome]], [[Itinerarium Burdigalense|Itin[erarium] Hierosol[ymitanum]]], [[Sozomen]], Eucherius [possibly [[Eucherius of Lyon]]], [[Benjamin of Tudela]], the Abbot Daniel,.... etc.) seem to point to the ruin of er Râmeh, near which is Beit el Khulil, or [[Abraham's House]], with a fine spring well. This is still held by the Jews to be the Oak of Mamre. The Christians point to another site, Ballûtet Sebta, where there is a fine specimen of Sindian ([[Quercus pseudococcifera|Quercus Pseudococcifera]])."<ref name="PPTS">{{cite web |url= https://archive.org/stream/libraryofpalesti03paleuoft#page/n57/mode/2up/search/hebron |title=The Pilgrimage of Arculfus in the Holy Land (About the Year A.D. 670) |author=Arculf |date=1895 |website=archive.org |publisher=[[Palestine Pilgrims' Text Society]] |location=London |pages=33–34 |access-date=2016-07-15}}</ref> ''Ballut'' is the Arabic word for oak.
The site of the oak was acquired in 1868 by [[Andrey Ivanovich Kapustin|Archimandrite Antonin (Kapustin)]] for the [[Church of Russia]], and the [[Abraham's Oak Holy Trinity Monastery|Monastery of the Holy Trinity]] was founded nearby. The site has since been a major attraction for Russian [[pilgrims]] before the revolution, and is the only functioning Christian shrine in the [[Hebron]] region. After the Russian Revolution, the property came under the control of the [[ROCOR]].
A long-standing tradition is that the ''Oak of Abraham'' will die before the appearance of the [[Antichrist]]. The main oak trunk has appeared to be dead since 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-6392441_ITM |title=Hebron's holy tree is dead but its successors live. |author= |date=27 December 1996 |work=accessmylibrary.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3PkGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5zYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7056,3033524&dq=mamre%20tree |title=Rome News-Tribune – Google News Archive Search |author= |date= |work=google.com}}</ref> Following construction work in the 1970s, a wooden ring in the form of a [[chalice]] was built around the tree, and its roots began to die. In 1997, a small [[sprig (agriculture)|sprig]] was seen growing near the withered oak. In October 2016, Russian botanists began a project to save the tree.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax-religion.com/?act=news&div=13359|title= Russian experts will work in Palestine to save the Oak of Mamre mentioned in Bible|date=October 24, 2016|work=[[Interfax]]}}</ref> In 1998 a root sprout appeared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravoslavie.ru/news/28900.htm|title=Российские специалисты проанализировали состояние Мамврийского дуба |author=|date= |work=pravoslavie.ru}}</ref>
The Hebron Monastery has emerged as a political issue between Russia and Palestinian authorities.
==References== {{OrthodoxWiki|name=Oak of Mamre |oldid=265708556}} {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{youtube|hcqRE4irCQ4|Video tour in English of Oak of Mamre and Holy Trinity Church in Hebron}}
{{coord missing|West Bank}}

See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Guatemala-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Guatemala.svg|189|Coat of arms of Guatemala.svg|118|The [[Flag of Guatemala]]|The [[Coat of arms of Guatemala]]}} [[Image:LocationGuatemala.svg|thumb|The location of [[Guatemala]]]] [[Image:Un-guatemala.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Republic of Guatemala]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Guatemala:
'''[[Guatemala]]''' – [[List of sovereign states|sovereign country]] located in [[Central America]] bordering [[Mexico]] to the northwest, the [[Pacific Ocean]] to the southwest, [[Belize]] and the [[Caribbean Sea]] to the northeast, and [[Honduras]] and [[El Salvador]] to the southeast.<ref name=CIA_World_Factbook>{{cite web|date=July 6, 2009|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/gt.html|title=Guatemala|work=[[The World Factbook]]|publisher=[[United States]] [[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=July 23, 2009}}</ref>
A [[representative democracy]], its capital is [[Guatemala City]]. The nation has been stable since the conclusion of the [[Guatemalan Civil War|Civil War]] in 1996 and has been in a state of continuous development and economic growth. Guatemala's abundance of biologically significant and unique ecosystems contribute to [[Mesoamerica]]'s designation as a [[biodiversity hotspot]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Biodiversity Hotspots-Mesoamerica-Overview |publisher= Conservation International |url= http://www.biodiversityhotspots.org/xp/Hotspots/mesoamerica/ |accessdate= 2007-02-01 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080704190529/http://www.biodiversityhotspots.org/xp/hotspots/Mesoamerica |archivedate= 2008-07-04 |df= }}</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight|auto=all | name = PROBA-2 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Technology]]
[[Space weather]] | operator = [[European Space Agency]]{{cite web |url=https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/p/proba-2 |title=PROBA-2 (Project for On-Board Autonomy-2) |publisher=[[ESA]] |accessdate = 2013-04-15}} | website = | COSPAR_ID = 2009-059B | SATCAT = 36037 | mission_duration = 2 years (planned) | spacecraft_bus = [[PROBA]] | manufacturer = [[Qinetiq|Verhaert Design & Development (now QinetiQ Space)]] | dry_mass = | launch_mass = {{convert|120|kg|lb}} | dimensions = 0.60m x 0.70m x 0.85m | power = 120 watts | launch_date = {{start-date|2 November 2009, 01:50:00|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Rokot]]/[[Briz-KM]] | launch_site = [[Plesetsk Cosmodrome|Plesetsk]] [[Plesetsk Cosmodrome Site 133|133/3]] | launch_contractor = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | last_contact = | decay_date = | orbit_epoch = 24 January 2015, 13:01:08 UTC{{cite web|url=http://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=36037|title=PROBA-2 Satellite details 2009-059B NORAD 36037|publisher=N2YO|date=24 January 2015|accessdate=25 January 2015}} | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Sun-synchronous orbit|Sun-synchronous]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|713|km|mi}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|733|km|mi}} | orbit_inclination = 98.28 degrees | orbit_period = 99.12 minutes | apsis = gee | insignia = Proba-2 insignia.png | insignia_caption = ESA solar system insignia for the ''PROBA-2'' mission | insignia_alt = ''PROBA-2'' mission logo | insignia_size = 180x180px }} '''PROBA-2''' is the second satellite in the [[European Space Agency]]'s series of [[PROBA]] low-cost [[satellite]]s that are being used to validate new spacecraft technologies while also carrying scientific instruments.{{cite web |url=http://www.esa.int/Our_Activities/Technology/Proba_Missions/About_Proba-2 |title=About PROBA-2 |date=2012-12-02 |publisher=[[ESA]] |accessdate = 2013-04-15}} PROBA-2 is a small satellite (130 kg) developed under an ESA General Support Technology Program (GSTP) contract by a Belgian consortium led by Verhaert (now [[QinetiQ|QinetiQ Space]]) of Kruibeke, Belgium. The nominal mission duration was two years. The mission's most recent extension runs to {{Date|2016-12-31}}.{{cite web |url=http://sci.esa.int/director-desk/54999-working-life-extensions-for-esas-science-missions/ |title=Working life extensions for ESA’s science missions |date=28 November 2014 |website=ESA Science & Technology |publisher=[[European Space Agency|ESA]] |access-date=9 May 2015}} ==Mission summary== It was launched on {{Date|2009-11-2}}, with the [[Rockot]] launch system together with [[ESA]]'s [[Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity satellite|SMOS]] mission.{{cite web |url=http://news.eoportal.org/didyouknow/080923_did1.html |title=Successful launch qualification test for PROBA-2 |date=2008-09-16 |publisher=[[ESA]] |accessdate=2013-04-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725074327/http://news.eoportal.org/didyouknow/080923_did1.html |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} The platform was launched in a [[Sun-synchronous orbit|sun-synchronous]] [[low Earth orbit]] (altitude of 725 km). PROBA-2 contains five scientific instruments. Two of them are designated to observe the [[Sun]]: "The Sun Watcher using APS and Image Processing" ([[SWAP (instrument)|SWAP]], an EUV imager) and the "Large Yield Radiometer" ([[LYRA]]), a radiometer made of diamond photodiodes. The Principal investigator teams of both instruments are hosted at the [[Royal Observatory of Belgium]]. This institute will also host the [http://proba2.oma.be PROBA-2 Science Center] from which the [[SWAP (instrument)|SWAP]] and [[LYRA]] instruments will be operated and their data distributed. There are three other instruments to measure basic space plasma properties: the [[Dual segmented Langmuir probe]] (DSLP) (developed by the [[Astronomical Institute of Czech Academy of Sciences|Astronomical Institute]] and Institute of Atmospheric Physics, Academy of Sciences of the Czech Republic), the Thermal Plasma Measurement Unit (TPMU), and the Science Grade Vector Magnetometer (SGVM) developed by the [[Technical University of Denmark]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==See also== *[[List of European Space Agency programs and missions]] *[[PROBA-1]] *[[PROBA-V]] *[[PROBA-3]] ==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[http://Proba2.oma.be PROBA-2 Science Center] {{European Space Agency}} {{Sun spacecraft}} {{Satellite and spacecraft instruments}} {{Orbital launches in 2009}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 2009]] [[Category:European Space Agency satellites]] [[Category:Environmental science]] [[Category:Space Situational Awareness Programme]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched by Rokot rockets]] [[Category:Solar space observatories]] [[Category:Technology demonstrations]] {{ESA-stub}} {{Europe-spacecraft-stub}}

{{Other people|Paul Curran}} '''Sir Paul James Curran''' (born 17 May 1955) is President of [[City University London|City, University of London]]. He took up his post in August 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.perrettlaver.com/news/article/99|title = New Vice-Chancellor for City University|publisher=Perrett Laver}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.city.ac.uk/blogs/city-alumni/2010/11/12/professor-paul-curran/|title = Interview with our new Vice-Chancellor |publisher=City University London}}</ref> Following a period of significant progress, City joined the University of London federation in September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/city-university-london-join-university-london|title = City University London to join University of London|publisher=[[Times Higher Education]]}}</ref> He previously served as Vice-Chancellor of [[Bournemouth University]] (2005–10) and Deputy Vice-Chancellor at the [[University of Southampton]] where he is currently a Visiting Professor.<ref>[http://www.southampton.ac.uk/geography/about/staff/ggcurran.page University homepage]</ref> As a member of the senior management team at Southampton, progressing from Head of Geography to Dean of Science, Curran was credited with high-profile leadership as Head of the [[Winchester School of Art]], part of the [[University of Southampton]].
==Biography== A former [[NASA]] research scientist and advisor to the [[European Space Agency]],<ref>The European Space Agency Earth Science Advisory Committee.</ref> Curran's research interests include investigations into global environmental change, in particular the movement of carbon between the atmosphere and forests. His award-winning work in Earth observation, involving the use of satellite sensors to monitor the environment at local to global scales, is widely published and he is the youngest recipient of the Remote Sensing Society’s Gold Medal.
He is Chair of the national Review Body on Doctors' and Dentists' Remuneration (DDRB),<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.ome.uk.com/Professor_Paul_Curran.aspx |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130630131954/http://www.ome.uk.com/Professor_Paul_Curran.aspx |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 2013-06-30 |title = DDRB Review Body Member Biographies }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Professor Paul Curran named Chair of the Review Body on Doctors’ and Dentists’ Remuneration|url=http://www.city.ac.uk/news/2013/apr/professor-paul-curran-named-chair-of-the-review-body-on-doctors-and-dentists-remuneration|work=www.city.ac.uk|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Public Appointments to the Review Body on Doctors’ and Dentists’ Remuneration|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/public-appointments-to-the-review-body-on-doctors-and-dentists-remuneration|work=www.gov.uk|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> where his 2015 report on hospital doctors' contracts sparked controversy and a series of strikes by the medical community in a stated attempt to the move to seven-day-a-week healthcare services;<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/412151/DDRB_47332_Accessible.pdf|title = Review Body on Doctors' and Dentists' Remuneration - Forty-Third Report 2015|publisher = Review Body on Doctors' and Dentists' Remuneration}}</ref> Founding Chair of the Board of Trustees for [[The Conversation (website)#The Conversation UK|The Conversation UK]];<ref>{{cite web|title=The Conversation UK Board of Trustees|url=http://theconversation.com/uk/team#board-of-trustees|website=The Conversation UK}}</ref> a Member of the Board of Trustees for [https://www.londonhigher.ac.uk/ London Higher;]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.londonhigher.ac.uk/about/london-higher-board/|title=London Higher Board – London Higher|work=London Higher|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-GB}}</ref> a Member of [[Universities UK]] and its Research Policy and Innovation & Growth Policy Committees and President of [http://www.rspsoc.org.uk the Remote Sensing and Photogrammetry Society]. He was Chair of the [[Universities and Colleges Employers Association]] (UCEA) Board and led the employers' negotiating team in the national pay negotiations;,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.ucea.ac.uk/en/About_Us/UCEA_Board_Membership.cfm|title = UCEA Board Membership|publisher=Universities and Colleges Employers Association}}</ref> a Member of the [[Natural Environment Research Council]] (NERC) and its Remuneration Committee and the Chair of its Audit & Risk Assurance Committee;<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.nerc.ac.uk/about/work/boards/council/biographies.asp|title = NERC Council biographies|publisher=[[Natural Environment Research Council]]}}</ref> the Chair of the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]] (HEFCE), Higher Education Workforce Steering Group and a Member of the [[Quality Assurance Agency]] (QAA) Board and its Remuneration and Audit Committees.
Curran received a [[BSc]] from the [[University of Sheffield]] in 1976, an [[MBA]] from the [[University of Southampton]] in 1998 and [[PhD]] and [[DSc]] degrees from the [[University of Bristol]] in 1979 and 1991 respectively. He is a Chartered Geographer and a Fellow of the [[Royal Geographical Society]], [http://www.rspsoc.org.uk Remote Sensing and Photogrammetry Society] and [[Chartered Management Institute]]. His PhD was followed by academic appointments at the Universities of [[University of Reading|Reading]] and [[University of Sheffield|Sheffield]] before moving to [[NASA Ames Research Center]] in 1988. He held established Chairs in Physical Geography at the [[University of Wales, Swansea]] from 1990 and the [[University of Southampton]] from 1993.
==Personal life== Curran is married, with one daughter. His leisure interests include boating and middle distance running.<ref>{{cite web|title=Who's Who|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/public/home.html|publisher=[[A & C Black]]|date=2011}}</ref>
==Honours== In 2007, Queen [[Elizabeth II]] approved the award of the [[Gold Medal (RGS)|Patron’s Medal]] of the [[Royal Geographical Society]] for his ‘international development of geographical science through remote sensing and Earth observation’.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.geographical.co.uk/Magazine/Golden_Achievers_Feb08.html|title = Golden Achievers|publisher = Geographical.co.uk|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120107090920/http://www.geographical.co.uk/Magazine/Golden_Achievers_Feb08.html|archivedate = 7 January 2012|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Curran was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[2016 New Year Honours]] for services to higher education.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=61450|supp=y|page=N2|date=30 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New Year’s Honours 2016 list|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/489049/NY2016HonoursFullList.pdf|website=GOV.UK|accessdate=30 December 2015|format=pdf|date=30 December 2015}}</ref>
==Select works== *Phenology of Vegetation (2011) *Evaluation of Envisat (2011) *Validating the MERIS (2010) *Indian Ocean Tsunami (2007) *Landcover Classification (2007) *Evaluation of the MERIS (2007) *Relating SAR Image Texture (2005) *The MERIS Terrestrial Chlorophyll Index (2004) *A Comparison of Texture Measures (2004) *The Slope of the Playing Field (1994)
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Prime Minister of the Cook Islands

revision.text:
{{Infobox Political post |post = Prime Minister |body = the
Cook Islands |insignia = Flag of the Cook Islands.svg |insigniasize = 125px |insigniacaption = Flag of the Cook Islands |termlength = |image = Henry Puna 2015.jpg |imagesize = 150px |incumbent = [[Henry Puna]] |incumbentsince = 30 November 2010 |appointer = |formation = 4 August 1965 |inaugural = [[Albert Henry (politician)|Albert Henry]] |website = }} {{Politics of the Cook Islands}} The '''Prime Minister of the Cook Islands''' is the [[head of government]] of the [[Cook Islands]], a self-governing territory in [[Associated state|free association]] with [[New Zealand]]. The office was established in 1965, when [[History of the Cook Islands|self-government]] was first granted to the islands. Originally, the title "Premier" was used, but this was replaced by the title of "Prime Minister" in 1981. ==List of Premiers/Prime Ministers of the Cook Islands (1965–present)== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- align=center bgcolor=#ebebeb !rowspan=2|№ !rowspan=2|Name

{{small|(1917–2007)}} | 16 November 1983 | 29 July 1987 | [[Democratic Party (Cook Islands)|Democratic Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Democratic Party (Cook Islands)/meta/color}}; color:white"| 4 | [[Pupuke Robati]]
{{small|(1925–2009)}} | 29 July 1987 | 1 February 1989 | [[Democratic Party (Cook Islands)|Democratic Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Cook Islands Party/meta/color}}; color:white"| {{small|(3)}} | [[Geoffrey Henry]]
{{small|(1940–2012)}} | 1 February 1989 | 29 July 1999 | [[Cook Islands Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Cook Islands Party/meta/color}}; color:white"| 5 | [[Joe Williams (Cook Islands politician)|Joe Williams]]
{{small|(1934–)}} | 29 July 1999 | 18 November 1999 | [[Cook Islands Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Democratic Party (Cook Islands)/meta/color}}; color:white"| 6 | [[Terepai Maoate]]
{{small|(1934–2012)}} | 18 November 1999 | 11 February 2002 | [[Democratic Party (Cook Islands)|Democratic Alliance Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Democratic Party (Cook Islands)/meta/color}}; color:white"| 7 | [[Robert Woonton]]
{{small|(1949–)}} | 11 February 2002 | 11 December 2004 | [[Democratic Party (Cook Islands)|Democratic Alliance Party]] |- ! style="background:{{Democratic Party (Cook Islands)/meta/color}}; color:white"| 8 | [[Jim Marurai]]

revision.text:
[[Budapest]] is the capital of [[Hungary]]. Below is a list of '''public place names of Budapest''' that refer to famous people, cities or historic events. Generality of Budapest's public place names relate to the Hungarian national history. In Budapest there are about 8,600 named [[public place]] (streets, squares, parks etc.).
==Notable people==
*[[András Áchim]], Hungarian peasant politician *[[Endre Ady]], Hungarian poet *[[Albrecht Dürer|Dürer Ajtósi]], Hungarian-German painter *[[High Prince Álmos]], ancient Hungarian leader, father of [[Árpád]] *[[Gyula Andrássy]], Hungarian statesman, see: [[Andrássy út]] *[[István Angyal]], Freedom fighter of the [[Hungarian revolution of 1956]] *[[János Apáczai Csere]], Hungarian writer and pedagogue *[[Vilmos Apor]], bishop, [[Righteous among the Nations]] *[[János Arany]], Hungarian poet, see: [[Arany János utca]] *[[Árpád]], ancient Hungarian leader, "father of the [[Hungarians]]", see: [[Árpád híd]] *[[Kemal Atatürk]], statesman of Turkey *[[Attila the Hun|Attila]], king of the [[Huns]] *[[Lajos Aulich]], Minister of War during [[Hungarian revolution of 1848]] *[[Mihály Babits]], Hungarian poet *[[Endre Bajcsy-Zsilinszky]], Hungarian anti-fascist politician during [[World War II]], see: [[Bajcsy-Zsilinszky út]] *[[József Bajza]], Hungarian poet, see: [[Bajza utca]] *[[Bálint Balassi]], Hungarian poet *[[Gábor Baross]], Hungarian statesman *[[Béla Bartók]], Hungarian composer *[[István Báthory]], [[prince of Transylvania]] *[[Lajos Batthyány]], The first [[prime minister of Hungary]], see: [[Batthyány tér]] *[[Sándor Bauer]], Hungarian student, victim of the communism *[[József Bem]], Polish general during [[Hungarian revolution of 1848]], national hero *[[Miklós Bercsényi]], [[Kuruc]] general *[[Dániel Berzsenyi]], Hungarian poet *[[György Bessenyei]], Hungarian poet *[[Gábor Bethlen]], [[prince of Transylvania]] *[[János Bihari]], Hungarian Gypsi musician *[[Lujza Blaha]], Hungarian actress, see: [[Blaha Lujza tér]] *[[István Bocskai]], [[prince of Transylvania]] *[[Simón Bolívar]], "The Liberator" *[[János Bolyai]], Hungarian mathematician *[[Winston Churchill]], [[prime minister of the UK]] *[[Prince Csaba|Csaba]], mythological King of the [[Székelys]] *[[Mihály Csokonai Vitéz]], Hungarian poet *[[János Csonka]], Hungarian inventor *[[Leonardo da Vinci]], Italian polymath *[[Jenő Dalnoki]], Hungarian footballer *[[János Damjanich]], general during [[Hungarian revolution of 1848]], national hero *[[Ferenc Deák]], Hungarian For example, there are 8 [[Kolozsvár]] streets and 9 [[Košice|Kassa]] streets.
== Most common public place names == *17x : [[Lajos Kossuth]], [[István Széchenyi]] *16x : [[Sándor Petőfi]] *14x : [[János Hunyadi]], [[Mátyás király]], [[Ferenc Rákóczi]] *13x : [[János Arany]], [[József Bem]], [[Mór Jókai]], [[Liberty|Szabadság]], [[Stephen I of Hungary|Szent István]], [[Mihály Vörösmarty]] *12x : [[Árpád]], [[Gábor Baross]] *11x : [[Endre Ady]], [[Attila the Hun|Attila]], [[Brasov|Brassói]], [[Ferenc Deák]], [[József Eötvös]], [[Elisabeth of Bavaria|Erzsébet]], [[Attila József]] *10x : [[High Prince Álmos|Álmos]], [[Lajos Batthyány]], [[István Bocskai]], [[Košice|Kassa]], [[György Klapka]], [[Sun|Nap]], [[Pozsony]] etc.
== Former public place names == *Moszkva tér ([[Moscow]] Square), 1951-2011, now [[Széll Kálmán tér]] *Lenin körút ([[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]] Boulevard), 1970-1990, now Erzsébet and Teréz körút *Sztálin út ([[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]] Avenue), 1950-1956, now [[Andrássy Avenue]] **Népköztársaság útja (Avenue of the People's Republic), 1957-1990, now Andrássy Avenue *Majakovszkij utca ([[Mayakovsky]] street), 1950-1990, now Király utca *Tolbuhin körút ([[Fyodor Tolbukhin|Tolbukhin]] Boulevard), 1945-1990, now Vámház körút *Dimitrov tér ([[Georgi Dimitrov|Dimitrov]] Square), 1949-1991, now Fővám tér *Hitler tér ([[Adolf Hitler|Hitler]] Square), 1938-1945, now [[Kodály körönd]] *Roosevelt tér ([[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]] Square), 1945-2011, now [[Széchenyi István]] tér *Mussolini tér ([[Benito Mussolini|Mussolini]] Square), 1936-1945, now [[Oktogon (intersection)|Oktogon]] ** November 7. tér ([[Bolshevik Revolution|7 November]] Square), 1950-1990, now Oktogon *Marx tér ([[Karl Marx|Marx]] Square), 1950-1990, now Nyugati tér *Felszabadulás tér ("[[Soviet occupation of Hungary|Liberation]]" Square), 1953-1990, now [[Ferenciek tere]] *Élmunkás tér (lit. "Top Worker" Square) until 1990, now [[Lehel tér]]

[[File:Zagreb areal view (4).jpg|thumb|Aerial view of Republic of Croatia Square]] [[File:University of Zagreb.jpg|thumb|University of Zagreb Faculty of Law (1856)]] [[File:Muzej za umjetnost i obrt.JPG|thumb|Museum of Arts and Crafts (1880)]] [[File:Hrvatski školski muzej.jpg|thumb|Croatian School Museum (1889)]] [[File:Leksikografski Zavod Miroslav Krleža.jpg|thumb|Miroslav Krleža Lexicographical Institute (1891)]] [[File:National Theatre in Zagreb.jpg|thumb|Croatian National Theatre (1895)]] [[File:Akademija dramskih umjetnosti.jpg|thumb|[[Academy of Dramatic Art, University of Zagreb|Academy of Dramatic Art]]]] [[File:Nova zgrada Muzičke akademije u Zagrebu.jpg|thumb|[[Academy of Music, University of Zagreb|Zagreb Academy of Music]]]]
'''Republic of Croatia Square''' ({{lang-hr|Trg Republike Hrvatske}}) is one of the biggest squares in [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]]. The square is located in [[Donji grad (Zagreb)|Lower Town]], with the [[Croatian National Theatre in Zagreb|Croatian National Theatre]] building at its centre. It is sometimes billed as the "most beautiful square in Zagreb".<ref name="mich">{{cite news|url=http://www.viamichelin.co.uk/web/Datasheet/1bb65f7299e2503bf3ea2421e521b3c8/125195/Zagreb,%20the%20beautiful%20Croatian%20city?from=DIRECTORY|title=Zagreb, the beautiful Croatian city|last=Tresmontant|first=Emmanuel|date=6 October 2008|work=ViaMichelin.co.uk|publisher=[[ViaMichelin]]|accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref>
The present-day square was formed in the period between 1856 (when the former hospital was built on its northern side) and 1964 (when the ''Ferimport'' building was erected on the western side). However, the majority of buildings overlooking the square were built in the late 19th century in the [[Historicism (art)|historicist]] style of architecture.
Republic of Croatia Square was the first in line of three squares which form the west wing of the so-called [[Lenuci's Horseshoe|Lenuci's horseshoe]] ({{lang-hr|Lenucijeva potkova}}), a U-shaped belt of squares and parks designed by engineer [[Milan Lenuci]] in the late 19th century which frames the core part of Zagreb's city centre. The east wing of the belt is formed by the King Tomislav, Strossmayer and [[Nikola Šubić Zrinski Square|Zrinski]] squares, and the west wing by the Marulić, Mažuranić and Republic of Croatia squares, with the Botanical Garden connecting the two. The square is home to several cultural and educational institutions and several landmark sculptures.
==Timeline== {{unreferenced|section|date=October 2015}} *1855–1856 - The square begins to take shape with the first building constructed on its northern side, a hospital ran by [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Daughters of Charity]]. From 1868 to 1882 the building housed a tobacco factory, and when the factory was moved out in 1882 it was taken over by the [[University of Zagreb]]. Today it houses the Zagreb Faculty of Law and the university rectorate. It was designed by architect Ludwig von Zettl. *1864 - The area of the present-day square is used as a fair ground for the first trade fair held in Croatia, the First Dalmatian-Croatian-Slavonian Trade Exhibition ({{lang-hr|Prva dalmatinsko-hrvatska-slavonska gospodarska izložba}}), which was opened by ''[[Ban (title)|ban]]'' [[Josip Šokčević]] and attended by more than 3,000 companies from throughout Croatia and the [[Austrian Empire]]. *1874 - The building which today houses the ''[[Školska knjiga]]'' publishing company is built on the eastern side. Designed by Janko Jambrišak, it went through several renovations and modifications since then. *1876–1878 - A two-story house designed by [[Franjo Klein]] is built on the eastern side, originally as the headquarters of the Croatian chamber of commerce (''Hrvatsko gospodarsko društvo''). In 1922 a third floor was added; today it is part of the Faculty of Law. *1884 - The southern side of the square is closed, through the construction of the building which housed the ''[[Sokol]]'' [[gymnastics]] society and the ''Kolo'' folklore group. A revised design by architect Matija Antolec was used for the building. The west wing was added during the construction of the Croatian National Theatre 11 years later, which was originally used for storing theatre props (today it houses a spare balet hall, art workshops and heating systems for the theatre building). In 1969 the west wing was connected to the theatre via an underground tunnel. The rest of the building today houses the [[Academy of Dramatic Art, University of Zagreb|Academy of Dramatic Art]]. *1888 - The building housing the School of Crafts (''Obrtna škola'', today the School of Applied Arts and Design) and the [[Museum of Arts and Crafts, Zagreb|Museum of Arts and Crafts]] is built on the western side, designed by architect [[Hermann Bollé]]. *1889 - Eastern side takes its final form with the building of the Teacher's Association (''Učiteljski dom'', today the Croatian School Museum), designed by Leo Hönigsberg of the [[Hönigsberg & Deutsch]] architecture studio. *1891 - A two-story building built on the northwest corner, designed by [[Kuno Waidmann]] (today home of the [[Miroslav Krleža Lexicographical Institute]]). *1895 - The new building of the [[Croatian National Theatre in Zagreb|Croatian National Theatre]] designed by [[Fellner & Helmer]] opens (the theatre moves here from its old location in the [[Old City Hall (Zagreb)|Old City Hall]] in [[Gradec, Zagreb|Gradec]]). The inauguration is attended by Emperor [[Franz Joseph I of Austria|Franz Joseph]] and marked by a student protest who burned the Hungarian flag at [[Ban Jelačić Square]] (as the theatre was built during the reign of ''[[Ban (title)|ban]]'' [[Károly Khuen-Héderváry]] and the project was seen as part of his [[Magyarization]] policies). *1899 - A two-story house built on the eastern side, designed by Martin Pilar. In 1922 the building was reconstructed and a third floor and a [[mansard roof]] were added, based on the designs by Oton Goldscheider. Today it houses the ''Kazališna kavana'' ([[English language|English]]: Theatre Cafe). *1903 - [[Vienna Secession|Secessionist]]-style building erected on the southwest corner, designed by [[Vjekoslav Bastl]] for Hönigsberg & Deutsch * 1911–1912 - The northern part of the square undergoes redecoration, designed by Ignjat Fischer. Obelisk-shaped candelabra which were built in front of the National Theatre moved to the [[Mirogoj cemetery]] and [[Ivan Meštrović]]'s sculpture ''Well of Life'' was installed in its place. * 1913 - East of the ''Kolo'' building, Frank House was erected, designed by [[Viktor Kovačić]] in the Renaissance Revival style * 1964 - The ''Željpoh'' building (later known as ''Ferimport'' building) built on the western side of the square, designed by [[Stanko Fabris]]. * 2014 - ''Željpoh'' building demolished in 2009, the new building of the [[Zagreb Academy of Music]] was built on its location, and opened in September 2014.
== Sculptures == [[File:Sv juraj.jpg|thumb|St. George Killing the Dragon by [[Anton Dominik Fernkorn]]]] * ''St. George Killing the Dragon'' by [[Anton Dominik Fernkorn]]<ref name="hrt1">{{cite web|url=http://www.hrt.hr/arhiv/ndd/03ozujak/0317%20Fernkorn.html |title=Na današnji dan - Anton Dominik Fernkorn |publisher=[[Croatian Radiotelevision]] |language=Croatian |accessdate=6 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229144557/http://www.hrt.hr/arhiv/ndd/03ozujak/0317%20Fernkorn.html |archivedate=29 December 2007 |df= }}</ref> located in the southwest corner; made in 1853 in [[Vienna]], the sculpture was bought and brought to Zagreb by [[Juraj Haulik]] in 1867, when it was placed at the entrance of [[Maksimir Park]]. In 1884 it was handed over to the City of Zagreb and then moved first to Strossmayer square before being moved again and installed at its current location in 1907. [[File:Zdenac života (Meštrović) 1.jpg|thumb|[[Well of Life (sculpture)|Well of Life]] by sculptor [[Ivan Meštrović]]]] * [[Well of Life (sculpture)|''Well of Life'']], designed by sculptor [[Ivan Meštrović]] in front of the Croatian National Theatre building; created in 1905 and installed in 1912. * ''History of Croats'' by Ivan Meštrović, in front of the Faculty of Law; created in 1932. * Monument to [[Đuro Deželić]] (1838-1907), writer and politician and founder of firefighting in Croatia, on the west side of the square, in front of the ''Ferimport'' building; designed by sculptor Frane Cota and commissioned by the Croatian Firefighting Association, the monument was erected in 1937.<ref name="garcin">{{cite web|url=http://dvd-garcin.blogspot.com/|title=Vatrogastvo na tlu Hrvatske|date=1 June 2009|publisher=DVD Garčin|language=Croatian|accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref>
==Former names== Being one of the most prominent squares in Zagreb its name was often changed in accordance to political circumstances of the time. The last change happened in 2017, as citizens' groups were lobbying for another name change on the grounds that [[Josip Broz Tito]] is a negative historical personality, due to his involvement in the many deaths during the rule of his communist regime.<ref name="index1">{{cite web|url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/inicijativa-krug-za-trg-na-trgu-marsala-tita-ni-jedno-mjesto-se-ne-smije-zvati-njegovim-imenom/436932.aspx|title=Inicijativa Krug za trg na Trgu maršala Tita: "Ni jedno mjesto se ne smije zvati njegovim imenom"|date=6 June 2009|publisher=Index.hr|language=Croatian|accessdate=6 March 2010}}</ref> The following is a complete list of names the square carried throughout its history.<ref name="snjeska1">{{cite book|last=Knežević|first=Snješka|title=Zagrebačka zelena potkova|publisher=[[Školska knjiga]]|location=Zagreb|date=1996|isbn=953-0-60524-2 |language=Croatian}}</ref>
*1878–1888 ''Sajmišni trg'' ([[Fair]]ground Square) *1888–1919 ''Sveučilišni trg'' (University Square) *1919–1927 ''Wilsonov trg'' ([[Woodrow Wilson]] Square) *1927–1941 ''Trg kralja Aleksandra I.'' (King [[Alexander I of Yugoslavia|Alexander I]] Square) *1941–1945 ''Trg I.'' (Square No. 1) *1945–1946 ''Kazališni trg'' (Theatre Square) *1946–2017 ''Trg maršala Tita'' ([[Josip Broz Tito|Marshal Tito]] Square) *2017–present ''Trg Republike Hrvatske'' (Republic of Croatia Square)
===Name Change Controversy=== In February 2008 about 2000 protesters, dressed in red aprons, gathered at the Marshal Tito Square, as it was known at the time, demanding the square to be renamed Theatre Square. Some 200 supporters of [[Josip Broz Tito|Marshal Tito]] also assembled at the opposite end of the square. The police prevented the two groups from coming in contact with each other. Zagreb's Mayor Milan Bandić said that there is no historic reason to change the name of the square.<ref>{{cite web|last1=New Europe Brussels team|title=Marshal Tito Square brings Controversy|url=http://www.neurope.eu/article/marshal-tito-square-brings-controversy/|website=neurope|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=AFP|title=Thousands of Croatians rally against Tito Square|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/region.php?yyyy=2008&mm=02&dd=10&nav_id=47607|website=b92|accessdate=28 June 2015}}</ref> However, in June, 2017, the same mayor stated that he would suggest the square to be renamed and that the new name would be the Square of the Republic of Croatia. <ref>http://dnevnik.hr/vijesti/hrvatska/ipak-preimenovanje-bandic-ima-novo-ime-za-trg-marsala-tita---480965.html</ref><ref>https://www.vecernji.hr/zagreb/milan-bandic-trg-marsala-tita-1178838</ref><ref>http://vijesti.hrt.hr/394027/bandic-neka-se-trg-marsala-tita-preimenuje-u-trg-republike-hrvatske</ref> Square was officially renamed by the City of Zagreb Assembly, on 31 August/1 September 2017.<ref>[https://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/odluceno-je-trg-se-vise-ne-zove-po-marsalu-titu/991738.aspx Odlučeno je Trg se više ne zove po maršalu Titu]</ref>

{{redirects|Terra Bella|the US city|Terra Bella, California}}
'''SkySat''' is a constellation of sub-meter resolution [[Earth observation satellite]]s owned by [[Planet Labs]], providing imagery, high-definition video and analytics services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/ten-things-you-must-know-about-isro-s-record-launch-of-20-satellites/story-YJizWHqqhTYjoIyfcaMPBL.html|title=Ten things you must know about Isro’s record launch of 20 satellites|date=2016-06-21|work=https://www.hindustantimes.com/|access-date=2018-06-05|language=en}}</ref><ref name="planet">{{cite web|url=https://www.planet.com/pulse/terra-bella-officially-joins-planet/|title=Terra Bella Officially Joins Planet|work=planet.com|accessdate=18 April 2017}}</ref> Planet acquired the satellites with their purchase of Terra Bella (formerly Skybox Imaging), a [[Mountain View, California]]-based company founded in 2009 by Dan Berkenstock, Julian Mann, John Fenwick, and Ching-Yu Hu,<ref name="IEEE Spectrum">{{cite news|last=Perry|first=Tekla S.|title=Start-up Profile: Skybox Imaging|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/at-work/innovation/startup-profile-skybox-imaging|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=IEEE Spectrum|date=1 May 2013}}</ref> from Google in 2017.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url = http://www.satellitetoday.com/technology/2014/08/05/google-closes-skybox-imaging-purchase/|title = Google Closes Skybox Imaging Purchase|date = 2014-08-05|accessdate = 2014-08-10|website = Via Satellite|publisher = |last = Henry|first = Caleb}}</ref>
==Overview== [[File:Apple Park satellite view May 2017.jpg|thumb|SkySat image of [[Apple Park]] taken in May 2017]] The resolution of the SkySat satellite imagery and videos is high enough to observe objects that impact the global economy such as terrain, cars and shipping containers. The satellites can capture video clips lasting up to 90 seconds at 30 frames per second.<ref name="Scientific American">{{cite news|last=Wogan|first=David|title=High-definition video from space is available for purchase. Finally|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/plugged-in/2013/12/30/high-definition-video-from-space-is-available-for-purchase-finally/|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=Scientific American|date=30 December 2013}}</ref> The high-definition satellite video from SkySat satellites “could help us understand our world better by analyzing movement of goods and people, providing visual data about supply chains, shipping, industrial plant activity, and even humanitarian relief efforts.”<ref name="Scientific American" /> [[File:Monte Fitz Roy 19Mar2018 SkySat.jpg|thumb|SkySat off-[[nadir]] image of [[Fitz Roy]]]] The constellation's goal is to be able to provide high-resolution satellite imagery of any place on Earth multiple times a day.<ref name="TechCrunch 4.12">{{cite news|last=Burns|first=Matt|title=Skybox Imaging Raises $70M To Launch Two High-Res Imaging Microsatellites|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/04/17/skybox-imaging-closes-70m-in-series-c-funding-with-immediate-plans-to-lauch-two-high-res-imaging-microsatellites/|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=TechCrunch|date=17 April 2012}}</ref> When Skybox originally delevoped the satellites, they planned to "change the nature" of the satellite industry by building satellites with "off-the-shelf" electronics that cost under $50 million.<ref name="FastCo 12.13">{{cite news|last=Truong|first=Alice|title=Proof That Cheaper Satellites Still Can Take Incredibly Detailed Photos of Earth|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3023325/fast-feed/proof-that-cheaper-satellites-still-can-take-incredibly-detailed-photos-of-earth?partner|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=Fast Company|date=11 December 2013}}</ref>
==Satellite constellation== The SkySat satellites are based on the [[CubeSat]] concept, using inexpensive automotive grade electronics and fast commercially available processors,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skybox.com/technology#satellite-sensors|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317060559/http://www.skybox.com/technology#satellite-sensors|title=High-Performance Satellites|work=Skybox Imaging|archive-date=17 March 2015|access-date=17 March 2017|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref>, but scaled up to approximately the size of a [[Refrigerator|minifridge]].<ref name="startup-skybox">{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2013/06/startup-skybox/|title=Inside a Startup's Plan to Turn a Swarm of DIY Satellites Into an All-Seeing Eye|website=wired.com|accessdate=4 November 2017}}</ref> The satellites are approximately 80cm long, compared to approximately 30cm for a 3U CubeSat, and weigh 220lbs.<ref name="startup-skybox" />
The satellites are manufactured by [[SSL (company)|SSL]],<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://www.sslmda.com/html/pressreleases/2017-09-05-High-Resolution-Smallsats-Built-by-SSL-Arrive-at-Vandenberg-AFB-for-Launch.php|title=High Resolution Smallsats Built by SSL Arrive at Vandenberg AFB for Launch|work=sslmda.com|publisher=Space Systems/Loral, LLC|date=5 September 2017|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref> the optical payloads are built by [[L3 Technologies]],<ref>{{cite web|title=REQUEST OF SKYBOX IMAGING, INC. FOR DETERMINATION OF COMPLIANCE WITH SATELLITE IMPLEMENTATION MILESTONES |url=http://licensing.fcc.gov/myibfs/download.do?attachment_key=987872|website=Federal Communications Commission|accessdate=1 November 2017|date=4 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=6skysats>{{cite press release|title=Planet Doubles Sub-1 Meter Imaging Capacity With Successful Launch Of 6 SkySats|url=https://www.planet.com/pulse/planet-doubles-sub-1-meter-imaging-capacity-with-successful-launch-of-6-skysats/|website=www.planet.com|publisher=Planet Labs Inc.}}</ref> and the satellite thrusters are provided by [[ECAPS]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Henry|first1=Caleb|title=Terra Bella’s SkySat 3 Green Propulsion System Declared Operational - Via Satellite -|url=http://www.satellitetoday.com/publications/st/2016/08/05/terra-bellas-skysat-3-green-propulsion-system-declared-operational/|accessdate=1 November 2017|work=Via Satellite|date=5 August 2016}}</ref>
== History == By April 2012, Skybox Imaging had raised a total of {{USD|91 million}} of [[private capital]] from [[Khosla Ventures]], [[Bessemer Venture Partners]], Canaan Partners and [[Norwest Venture Partners]] to develop the SkySat constellation.<ref name="TechCrunch 4.12" />
On November 21, 2013, the first satellite, SkySat-1, was launched on a [[Dnepr rocket]] from [[Yasny|Yasny, Russia]].<ref name="Spaceflight Now Nov 2013">{{cite web|last=Clark|first=Stephen|title=Silo-launched Dnepr rocket delivers 32 satellites to space|url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/news/n1311/21dnepr/#.U3FN-V4Sss2|work=Website|publisher=Spaceflight Now|accessdate=12 May 2014}}</ref> Less than a month later, on December 11, 2013, the first images captured by the SkySat-1 satellite, of [[Perth]], [[Abu Dhabi]], and the coast of [[Somalia]], were released.<ref name="Fast Company December 2013">{{cite web|last=Truong|first=Alice|title=Proof That Cheaper Satellites Still Can Take Incredibly Detailed Photos Of Earth|url= http://www.fastcompany.com/3023325/fast-feed/proof-that-cheaper-satellites-still-can-take-incredibly-detailed-photos-of-earth?partner |work=Website|publisher=Fast Company|accessdate=11 December 2013}}</ref> The second satellite, SkySat-2, launched on a [[Soyuz-2]]/Fregat rocket from Baikonur, Kazakhstan on July 8, 2014,<ref name="9to5Google July 2014">{{cite web|last=Hearn|first=Mark|title=Skybox Imaging successfully launches its SkySat-2 Earth observation satellite|url=http://9to5google.com/2014/07/08/skybox-imaging-successfully-launches-its-skysat-2-earth-observation-satellite/|work=Website|publisher=9to5Google|accessdate=8 July 2014}}</ref> The company plans to eventually launch a fleet of 24 satellites.<ref name="NYT 8.2013">{{cite news|last=Eisenberg|first=Anne|title=Microsatellites: What Big Eyes They Have|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/11/business/microsatellites-what-big-eyes-they-have.html?_r=4&adxnnl=1&adxnnlx=1378221470-gkZ8MehC6vPWWcz9FWCrbg&|accessdate=12 May 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=10 August 2013}}</ref> and released its first images within 48 hours of launch.<ref name="Satellite Today July 2014">{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Caleb|title=Skybox Imaging Releases First Images from SkySat 2|url= http://www.satellitetoday.com/technology/2014/07/11/skybox-imaging-releases-first-images-from-skysat-2/|work=Website|publisher=Satellite Today|accessdate=11 July 2014}}</ref>
On February 10, 2014, [[SSL (company)|SSL]] announced that Skybox had awarded it a contract to build 13 more satellites based on a revised "SkySat C" design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sslmda.com/html/pressreleases/pr20140210.html|title=Skybox Imaging Selects SSL To Build 13 Low Earth Orbit Imaging Satellites|work=sslmda.com|date=10 February 2014|accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=satellitetoday>{{cite web|url=http://www.satellitetoday.com/launch/2016/04/06/terra-bella-evaluating-launches-for-eight-skysats-by-2017/|title=Terra Bella Evaluating Launches for Eight SkySats by 2017|work=Satellite Today|publisher=Access Intelligence|date=6 April 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref> The first of these, Skysat-3, also referred to as SkySat-C1, was launched on June 22, 2016 by [[ISRO]] on [[PSLV]] [[PSLV-C34|flight C34]],<ref name=skysat3firstlight>{{cite web|url=http://terrabellatech.blogspot.com/2016/06/skysat-3-first-light.html|title=SkySat-3 First Light|work=Terra Bella Blog|publisher=Google, Inc.|date=28 June 2016|accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref><ref name=pslv34>{{cite web|url=http://spaceflight101.com/pslv-c34/pslv-c34-launch-success/|title=International Assortment of Satellites lifted by Indian PSLV Rocket |work=Spaceflight101.com|date=22 June 2016|accessdate= 11 August 2016}}</ref> with contract for four more satellites to launch.<ref name=isro20150419>{{cite web|title=VIKRAM SARABHAI SPACE CENTRE - PSLV|url=http://www.vssc.gov.in/VSSC_V4/index.php/launchers/launchers-pslv|publisher=ISRO|accessdate=18 April 2015}}</ref>{{fv|date=August 2016}}
On June 10, 2014, Skybox Imaging announced that it had entered into an agreement to be acquired by [[Google]] for {{USD|500 million}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investor.google.com/releases/2014/0609.html|title=Alphabet Investor Relations|work=google.com|date=9 June 2014|accessdate=11 August 2016}}</ref><ref name="Skybox Imaging Blog">{{cite news |title=Skybox Imaging + Google |accessdate=29 June 2016 |url=http://terrabellatech.blogspot.com/2014/06/skybox-imaging-google.html |date=8 June 2014}}</ref> The acquisition was completed on August 1, 2014.<ref name="Skybox Imaging Blog" /><ref name="auto"/> Skybox Imaging changed its name to "Terra Bella" on March 8, 2016, to indicate its focus on image analytics.<ref name="tcterrabella">{{cite news|last1=Lardinois|first1=Frederic|title=Google renames its satellite startup, Skybox Imaging, to Terra Bella and adds focus on image analysis|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/03/08/google-renames-its-satellite-startup-skybox-imaging-to-terra-bella-and-adds-focus-on-image-analysis/|accessdate=8 March 2016|work=TechCrunch|publisher=AOL Inc.|date=8 March 2016}}</ref> The new name was partially based on the Terra Bella Ave. in [[Mountain View, California]], where the company's headquarters are located.<ref name="vbterrabella">{{cite news|last1=Protalinski|first1=Emil|title=Google rebrands Skybox as Terra Bella, will launch ‘more than a dozen satellites’ over the next few years|url=https://venturebeat.com/2016/03/08/google-rebrands-skybox-as-terra-bella-will-launch-more-than-a-dozen-satellites-over-the-next-few-years/|accessdate=8 March 2016|work=VentureBeat|date=8 March 2016}}</ref> Terra bella is Italian for "beautiful earth".
Four more SkySat units were launched on September 16, 2016, by the [[Vega rocket]]'s seventh flight from [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2016/09/16/vega-rocket-hauls-up-quintet-of-earth-observation-satellites/ |title=Vega rocket hauls up quintet of Earth observation satellites |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=16 September 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, Google sold Terra Bella and its SkySat satellite constellation to [[Planet Labs]] for an undisclosed price and entered into a multi-year agreement to purchase SkySat imaging data.<ref name=PlanetLabsReuters>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-alphabet-terra-bella-sale-idUSKBN15I2Y8|title=Google sells satellite imaging business Terra Bella to Planet Labs|date=3 February 2017|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=3 February 2017}}</ref> Planet launched six more SkySat satellites, along with four Dove [[CubeSat]]s, on a [[Minotaur-C]] rocket from Vandenberg on October 31, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2017/10/orbital-atk-minotaur-c-skysat-mission-vandenberg/|title=Orbital ATK Minotaur-C launches SkySat mission out of Vandenberg|last=Graham|first=William|date=31 October 2017|work=NASASpaceFlight}}</ref><ref name=6skysats />
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Images by SkySat satellites|SkySat}} *[https://www.planet.com/products/hi-res-monitoring/ Official website]
[[Category:Google]] [[Category:Private spaceflight]] [[Category:Earth observation satellites]] [[Category:Analytics companies]] [[Category:Companies based in Mountain View, California]] [[Category:2009 establishments in California]] [[Category:Satellite imagery]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} {{Infobox Software | name = TerraFly | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = [[Florida International University]] - High Performance Database Research Center, directed by Naphtali David Rishe, Ph.D. | released = | latest_release_version = | latest_release_date = | programming language = | size = | operating system = | language = | genre = [[Virtual globe]] | license = | website = http://TerraFly.com }} '''TerraFly''' is a web-enabled system designed to aid in the visualization of spatial and remote sensed imagery. TerraFly users visualize [[aerial photography]], [[satellite imagery]] and various overlays, such as street names, roads, restaurants, services and demographic data. Users virtually "fly" over imagery via a web browser, without any software to install or plug in.<ref name="NASA TerraFly Summary">{{cite web |url=http://gcmd.nasa.gov/records/TerraFly.html| title= TerraFly Summary |publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
Terrafly's tools include geospatial querying, data drill-down, interfaces with real-time data suppliers, demographic analysis, annotation, route dissemination via autopilots, customizable applications, production of aerial atlases and application programming interface ([[API]]) for web sites.
== Media coverage == The TerraFly project has been featured on TV news programs and worldwide press. It has been covered by the New York Times,<ref name="New York Times article">{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9402E6DC1F38F932A3575BC0A9649C8B63&scp=1&sq=terrafly&st=cse| title= Zoom Out, Then Nosedive: A Bird's-Eye View of Your Burg |publisher=[[The New York Times]] | first=Amir | last=Tusher | date=2002-08-01 | accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref> USA Today, NPR,<ref name="NPR report">{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=10817208| title= NPR Technology Report by Greg Allen |publisher=[[NPR]]}}</ref> as well as Science and Nature journals. FOX News screened in July 2007 a worldwide broadcast on TerraFly assisting exiles in tracking their homeland property.<ref name="Fox News report ">{{cite web|url=http://n0.cs.fiu.edu/fox|title=Property check|publisher=[[Fox News]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112164853/http://n0.cs.fiu.edu/fox/|archivedate=2009-01-12|df=}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://gcmd.nasa.gov/records/TerraFly.html] - TerraFly Summary, NASA
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Atlases]] [[Category:Virtual globes]] [[Category:Virtual reality]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {|{{Infobox ship begin|infobox caption=''Bear''}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image=[[File:USS Bear (AG-29) Antarctica c1939.jpg|300px|border|alt=USS Bear in Antarctica, 1939]] |Ship caption=USS ''Bear'' (AG-29) in Antarctica, 1939 }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=[[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|UK|civil}} |Ship name=SS ''Bear'' |Ship owner=*W. Grieve, Sons & Company 1874–1879 * R. Steele Jr 1880–1883 |Ship operator= |Ship route= |Ship ordered= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=1874 |Ship builder=Alexander Stephen & Sons Ltd. [[Greenock]], Scotland |Ship completed= |Ship christened= |Ship acquired= |Ship maiden voyage= |Ship out of service= |Ship registry=[[St. John's, Newfoundland]] |Ship identification=Official No. 66,840 |Ship fate=Sold to U.S. government in 1884 |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country=United States |Ship flag={{USN flag|1912}} |Ship name=* USRC ''Bear'' * USCGC ''Bear'' * USS ''Bear'' * ''Bear of Oakland'' (1926) * ''Arctic Bear'' (1948) |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned=1948 |Ship in service=1884–1929,<ref name=Bear1885>''Bear'', 1885</ref> 1939–1944 |Ship out of service=1926–1938 (museum ship); 1944–1948 (laid up) |Ship reinstated= |Ship honours= |Ship fate=Sold to Canadian owners for sealing in 1948 |Ship status= |Ship notes=Wireless call sign for USRC ''Bear'' was '''''RCB'''''.<ref>[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=njp.32101055258162;view=1up;seq=63 "List of Revenue Cutters"], ''WIRELESS TELEGRAPH STATIONS OF THE WORLD, INCLUDING SHORE STATIONS, MERCHANT VESSELS, U.S. REVENUE CUTTERS, AND VESSELS OF THE UNITED STATES NAVY.'' CORRECTED TO OCTOBER 1, 1910. U.S. DEPARTMENT OF THE NAVY. BUREAU OF STEAM ENGINEERING. WASHINGTON, D.C. U.S. GOVERNMENT PRINTING OFFICE : 1910, p. 59.</ref> }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country=Canada |Ship flag= {{shipboxflag|Canada|1921}} |Ship name=SS ''Arctic Bear'' |Ship owner=Shaw Steamship Line |Ship namesake= |Ship acquired= |Ship in service= |Ship registry=[[Halifax, Nova Scotia]] |Ship out of service=1948–1961 (protracted refits); 1962 (restaurant conversion) |Ship fate=Sank in the Atlantic, 19 March 1963, while being towed |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship type=ice strengthened aux. steamer 1 funnel, 3 masts |Ship displacement=703 tons |Ship length={{convert|198.5|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|30|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|18.8|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion= {{convert|300|ihp|lk=in|abbr=on}} compound steam engine, 1 screw |Ship rig=[[Barkentine]] |Ship speed= |Ship range=Limited by water and provisions |Ship complement=51 |Ship armament= |Ship aircraft= Carried Barkley-Grow seaplane on Byrd Expedition III |Ship notes= }} |}
For the later United States Coast Guard cutter see {{ship|USCGC|Bear|WMEC-901}}
The '''SS ''Bear''''' was a dual steam-powered and sailing ship built with {{convert|6|in|cm|adj=on|1|spell=in}}-thick sides which had a long life in various cold-water and ice-filled environs. She was a forerunner of modern [[icebreaker]]s and had an exceptionally diverse service life. According to the [[United States Coast Guard]] official website, ''Bear'' is described as "probably the most famous ship in the history of the Coast Guard."<ref>http://www.uscg.mil/pacarea/cgcHealy/history.asp</ref>
Built in Scotland in 1874 as a steamer for [[seal hunt|sealing]], she was owned and operated out of [[Colony of Newfoundland|Newfoundland]] for ten years. In the mid-1880s, she took part in the search for the [[Adolphus Greely|Greely]] Expedition.<ref>{{cite book | publisher = Government Printing Office | last = United States. Revenue-Cutter Service : | title = Report of the cruise of the U.S. Revenue Cutter Bear and the overland expedition for the relief of the whalers in the Arctic ocean, from November 27, 1897, to September 13, 1898 | location = Washington, D.C. | accessdate = 2014-03-23 | year = 1898 | url = https://archive.org/details/reportofcruiseof03unit }}</ref> Captained by [[Michael A. Healy|Michael Healy]] of the [[United States Revenue Cutter Service]] (later part of the U.S. Coast Guard), she worked the 20,000-mile coastline of [[Alaska]]. She later assisted with relief efforts after the [[1906 San Francisco earthquake]].
Her services also included the second expedition of Admiral [[Richard E. Byrd]] to [[Antarctica]], and again to the southernmost continent in 1941 to evacuate Americans at the beginning of [[World War II]]. She later served in patrol duty off the coast of [[Greenland]] for the [[United States Navy]]. Between some of these missions, she was a museum ship in [[Oakland, California]] and starred in the 1930 film version of [[Jack London]]'s ''[[The Sea-Wolf]]''.
After World War II, ''Bear'' was returned to use again as a sealing vessel. Finally, in 1963, 89 years after she had been built, while being towed to a stationary assignment as a [[floating restaurant]] in [[Philadelphia]], ''Bear'' foundered and sank in the [[North Atlantic Ocean]] about {{convert|100|mi}} east of [[Cape Sable Island]], [[Nova Scotia]].
==Construction and sealing career== ''Bear'' was built in 1874 as a sealer at Dundee, Scotland shipyards. Custom-built for sealing out of [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's, Newfoundland]], ''Bear'' was the most outstanding sealing vessel of her day, the lead ship in a new generation of sealers.<ref>Tod, Giles, M.S., ''Last Sail Down East'', Barre Publishers, (1965) p. 48</ref> Heavy-built with {{convert|6|in|cm|adj=on|1|spell=in}} thick wooden planks, ''Bear'' was rigged as a sailing [[barquentine]] but her main power was a steam engine designed to smash deep into ice packs to reach seal herds. At the time of her arrival in St. John's, there were 300 vessels outfitted each season to hunt seals, but most were small [[schooner]]s or old sailing [[barque]]s.<ref>Ryan, Shannon, ''The Ice Hunters: A History of Newfoundland Sealing to 1914'' (1994) Breakwater Books Ltd. {{ISBN|1-55081-095-2}}.</ref> The new sealing ships represented by ''Bear'' radically transformed the Eastern North Atlantic seal fishery as they replaced the hundreds of smaller sealing vessels owned by merchants in [[outport]]s around Newfoundland with large and expensive steamships owned by large British and Newfoundland companies based in St. John's.<ref>[http://www.heritage.nf.ca/law/sealing_disaster.html "1914 Sealing Disaster", Newfoundland and Labrador Heritage'']</ref> Owned at first by the Scottish firm W. Grieve and Sons, she was acquired in 1880 by R. Steele Junior.<ref>''Lloyds Register'' 1875-1883</ref> ''Bear'' spent a decade sealing from St. John. In 1884, the Steeles sent ''Bear'' back to Scotland for a refit.
==American government service== [[File:Loading Reindeer on U.S.S. Bear, c.1896.jpg|thumb|left|Men loading Reindeer onto USRC ''Bear''.]]
The massive wooden hulls of Newfoundland sealing vessels had proved ideal for arctic exploration. Just back from her refit in 1884 and ready for another season of sealing, ''Bear'' was instead purchased by the US government in 1884 and took part in the search for the [[Lady Franklin Bay Expedition]], whose seven survivors were found at [[Cape Sabine]].
From 1885 to 1926, ''Bear'' served as a [[United States Revenue Cutter Service]] cutter, making the seasonal trek each May from her port in [[Oakland, California]] to sail north to [[Alaska|Alaskan]] waters for the five month season, cruising 10,000 miles on Bering Sea Patrol, where she looked out for seal poachers, shipwrecked whalers, and illicit trade with [[Alaska Natives]], ferried reindeer from [[Siberia]] to Alaska, and served as a floating courthouse.<ref name=Bear1885/> By order of the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of the Treasury]], ''Bear'' was given free run to arrest and seize possessions of poachers, smugglers and illegal traders, as well as take census of people and ships, record geological and astronomical information, take note of tides, and escort whaling ships.
One captain of ''Bear'', [[Michael A. Healy|Michael "Hell Roaring Mike" Healy]], was considered a savior by many of the whalers and native Eskimos, as he bought Siberian reindeer at his own expense for the starving natives to use as the foundation for a new herd in Alaska, paralleling, and possibly in cooperation with, missionary [[Sheldon Jackson]]. Healy was the first African-American commissioned officer in U.S. history, and during Captain Healy's and ''Bear''{{'}}s 1891 Bering Sea Patrol, the following was accomplished: * secured witnesses for a murder trial * ferried reindeer * sailed the Alaskan governor * transported a U.S. Geographical survey team * carried lumber and supplies for school construction in remote areas * delivered teachers to their remote assignments * delivered mail for the Postal Service * enforced federal laws * provided medical support to natives * conducted search and rescue<ref>[http://coastguard.dodlive.mil/2013/02/a-bear-of-a-sea-story/ ''A Bear of a sea story''], Coast Guard Compass: Official Blog of the U.S. Coast Guard, , February 12, 2013. {{PD-notice}}</ref>
During one of its yearly trips back to San Francisco, ''Bear'' assisted in rescue operations for 1906 San Francisco earthquake. The Revenue Cutter Service was merged with the [[United States Life-Saving Service]] to form the [[United States Coast Guard]] on 28 January 1915 and the ship was renamed USCGC ''Bear''.{{#tag:ref|After 28 January 1915 the Revenue Cutter Service was merged with the [[United States Life-Saving Service]] to form the [[United States Coast Guard]]. The prefix for Revenue Cutter Service vessels was changed from USRC to USCGC, thus; USRC ''Bear'' became USCGC ''Bear''.<ref name=USCG1915>"Coast Guard General Order No. 1", Historic Documents & Publications, U.S. Coast Guard Historian's Office</ref>|group=Note}}
{{anchor|Bear of Oakland}}
==''Bear of Oakland''== Cruising to Alaska for her last patrol in the 1926 season, on her return to Oakland that November she was replaced by a new cutter, {{USCGC|Northland|WPG-49|6}} and ownership was transferred to the city for use as a large [[barkentine]] rigged museum ship,<ref>[https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1927-03-27/ed-1/seq-73/#date1=1924&index=0&rows=20&words=Bear+Oakland&searchType=basic&sequence=0&state=&date2=1928&proxtext=%22bear+of+oakland%22&y=3&x=12&dateFilterType=yearRange&page=1 ''The (Washington) Evening Star'', March 27, 1927, p. 1]</ref> ''Bear'' starred as the sealer ''Macedonia'' in the 1930 film version of Jack London's ''[[The Sea Wolf (1930 film)|The Sea-Wolf]]''.<ref name="Burroughs 1970">{{cite book |last1=Burroughs |first1=Polly |title=The Great Ice Ship Bear: Eighty-Nine Years in Polar Seas |date=1970 |publisher=Van Nostrand Reinhold |pages=104 |accessdate=27 June 2018 |ref=ASIN: B0006CA9LC}}</ref>
In 1932 ''Bear of Oakland'' was purchased by Rear Admiral [[Richard E. Byrd]] for $1,050, as a replacement for the barquentine {{ship||City of New York|1885 ship|2}}. He used her in the [[Richard E. Byrd|Second Byrd Expedition]] alongside the old steel-hulled lumber ship ''Pacific Fir'', renamed by Byrd {{ship||Jacob Ruppert}}, in honor of the New York brewer who was a major sponsor of expedition.<ref name="Paine 2007">{{cite book |last1=Paine |first1=Stuart D. |title=Footsteps on the Ice: The Antarctic Diaries of Stuart D. Paine, Second Byrd Expedition |date=2007 |publisher=University of Missouri Press | |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qy8n8M_34BsC&pg=PA9&lpg |accessdate=27 June 2018 |ref=ASIN: B00VIBZ3B6}}</ref>
After the expedition, Admiral Byrd leased ''Bear'' to the Navy for one dollar a year, for use on his government sponsored (third) expedition.<ref name="Lynch">{{cite web |last1=Lynch Jr. |first1=Joseph |title=A Philatelic Introduction to B.A.E. III United States Antarctic Service Expedition 1939-41 |url=http://www.south-pole.com/p0000146.htm |website=south-pole.com |accessdate=27 June 2018}}</ref>
==United States Antarctic Service Expedition== On 11 September 1939 she was re-commissioned in the U.S. Navy for service during the 1939–1941 [[United States Antarctic Service Expedition]], led by Rear Admiral [[Richard E. Byrd]], and renamed USS ''Bear'' (AG-29). She carried a [[Barkley-Grow]] [[Barkley-Grow T8P-1|seaplane]] on board.<ref>http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/pastIssues/2004-2005/2004_11_28.pdf</ref> Lieutenant Commander [[Richard H. Cruzen]] was captain of ''Bear'' during the expedition. Cruzen would rise to the rank of [[Rear admiral (United States)|rear admiral]] and commanded the U.S. Navy ships which participated in a large Antarctic expedition named [[Operation Highjump]] in 1948.
In early 1941, USS ''Bear'' assisted in the evacuation of the members of the Antarctic Expedition, as international tensions rose in the months that led up to America's entrance into [[World War II]]. ''Bear'' arrived at the [[Mikkelsen Islands]], just north of the [[Antarctic Circle]], on 16 March 1941, and its crew helped to build an adequate [[airstrip]] to evacuate personnel and equipment from the expedition base in the area.
==World War II== From 1941 to 1944, USS ''Bear'' served in the Northeast Atlantic [[Greenland Patrol]]. The rigging was cut down to two masts to become a fully motorized ship. After the capture, on 12 September 1941, of the German-controlled Norwegian sealer {{SS|Buskø||2}}, which was used as a supply ship for secret weather stations, by {{USCGC|Northland|WPG-49|6}}, ''Bear'' towed the [[Prize law|prize]] to Boston.<ref name=NHHC01>{{cite web|title=Northland (WPG-49)|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/n6/northland.htm|work=Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships (DANFS)|publisher=Naval History and Heritage Command|accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref> When more modern ships were available to replace her, ''Bear'' was decommissioned on 17 May 1944 and laid up in Boston until the end of the war.<ref name=NHHC02>{{cite web|title=Bear|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/b4/bear-i.htm|work=Dictionary of American Fighting Ships (DANFS)|publisher=Naval History and Heritage Command|accessdate=28 August 2013}}</ref>
''Bear'' had the distinction of being the oldest U.S. Navy ship to be deployed outside the continental United States during World War II. She was also one of a very few U.S. Navy ships to have served during the [[Spanish–American War]] as well as both world wars. (The sailing relics {{USS|Constitution}} and {{USS|Constellation|1854|6}} were both in active commissioned service during World War II but neither left port during the war.)
==Postwar== ''Bear'' was purchased from the US government in 1948 by Frank M. Shaw of [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]] for $5,199. Shaw intended to use the ship for sealing. Renamed ''Arctic Bear'', her refit for sealing proved costly and with the decline of the large-scale Newfoundland seal hunt, she was laid up in [[Halifax Harbour]] subject to on and off again refits, and lay derelict for periods of times as she remained at various moorings around Halifax and [[Dartmouth, Nova Scotia|Dartmouth]].
By the early 1960s ''Bear'' was considered for restoration as a museum ship by the City of Dartmouth as well as her old home at Oakland and by the [[San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park|San Francisco marine museum]].<ref>"Famed Exploration Ship May Be Marine Museum", ''Halifax Mail'', 28 March 1982</ref> However the purchase price from Shaw Steamships and the extensive restoration costs scuttled museum plans.<ref>"Bear Project Scuttled. Vessel Refit Too Costly", ''Chronicle Herald'', 19 April 1962</ref>
In 1962 she was purchased by Alfred Johnston of Philadelphia for a floating seafood restaurant.<ref>Bixby, William , ''Track of the Bear'', p. 285</ref> Repairs were made to the ship at Industrial Shipping Limited in [[Mahone Bay, Nova Scotia]] for her new role including the carving of a new bear figurehead.
==Sinking== In 1963, while in tow by the tug ''Irving Birch'' to Philadelphia, ''Bear'' foundered about {{convert|100|nmi}} east of [[Cape Sable Island]], Nova Scotia, at {{coord|42|40|N|065|11|W|name=SS ''Arctic Bear''}}. She went down early in the morning of 19 March 1963 after a gale struck and severed the tow line. The mast collapsed and punctured the hull, causing the sinking. Her crew of two were rescued by ''Irving Birch''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://museum.gov.ns.ca/mma/wrecks/wrecks/shipwrecks.asp?ID=565# |title="Bear-1963", ''On the Rocks Shipwreck Database'' Nova Scotia Museum |access-date=2 October 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927161639/http://museum.gov.ns.ca/mma/wrecks/wrecks/shipwrecks.asp?ID=565# |archive-date=27 September 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Legacy== ''Bear''{{'}}s exceptional career lasted for 89 years. She spent a total of 47 years in commissioned service of the United States Revenue Cutter Service, Coast Guard and Navy. She served under the flags of three different nations (United Kingdom, United States and Canada). She was one of only a few ships to have served in both arctic regions.
There is a large detailed scale model of ''Bear'' on display in the Stockton Center for International Law, part of the [[United States Naval War College]] in [[Newport, Rhode Island]].
The figurehead from ''Bear'' is in the collection at the [[Mariners' Museum]] in [[Newport News, Virginia]].
==Awards== * [[Spanish Campaign Medal]] * [[World War I Victory Medal (United States)|World War I Victory Medal]] with "ASIATIC" clasp * [[Second Byrd Antarctic Expedition Medal]] * [[United States Antarctic Expedition Medal]] * [[American Defense Service Medal]] with "A" device * [[American Campaign Medal]] * [[European-African-Middle Eastern Campaign Medal]] * [[World War II Victory Medal]]
